topic: Wreck Your Procrastination with Absurd Deadlines

dialog.text: I keep putting things off. How do I actually stop procrastinating—something radical, not another planner?
dialog.instructions: Curious, slightly anxious; rising intonation at end; quick pacing; voice like someone confessing to a friend.

dialog.text: Give yourself an absurd deadline—something that sounds impossible. It’s less about the time and more about forcing your brain to start.
dialog.instructions: Calm, playful; confident tone; moderate pace; slight mischievous smile in the voice.

dialog.text: Absurd? Like ten minutes to write a report?
dialog.instructions: Incredulous, amused; short bursts; higher pitch on 'ten minutes'.

dialog.text: Yes. Say the report will be done in ten minutes. Your perfectionist brain freezes when there's infinite time—an absurd deadline breaks that loop.
dialog.instructions: Explanatory, brisk; warm authority; emphasize 'breaks that loop.'

dialog.text: Won’t the quality suck if I rush?
dialog.instructions: Worried but curious; soft tone; slight breath before 'suck'.

dialog.text: Maybe at first. But shipping a messy version creates momentum. I once knew a student who set a 20-minute slide-deadline with a ridiculous penalty—she had a draft and then polished it. Progress, then polish.
dialog.instructions: Storytelling, warm; inject a playful wink through the voice; steady pacing.

dialog.text: So it’s about momentum more than instant perfection?
dialog.instructions: Eager, relieved; slightly faster tempo; upward inflection at the end.

dialog.text: Exactly. Try this three-step trick: set an absurd deadline (10–30% of usual time), break the task into tiny sprints, then give a tiny reward or a silly penalty if you miss it.
dialog.instructions: Directive, punchy; count out steps clearly; upbeat tone.

dialog.text: What if I fail the deadline?
dialog.instructions: Nervous, hopeful; short and honest delivery.

dialog.text: Fail fast, learn faster. If you miss it, shorten the next sprint or change the consequence. The lesson isn’t flawless work—it’s discovering the friction that kept you stuck.
dialog.instructions: Reassuring, energetic; encouraging cadence; emphasize 'discovering the friction.'

dialog.text: Alright—set an absurd deadline, sprint, adjust, repeat. I can do that today.
dialog.instructions: Determined, bright; steady pace; sense of small victory.

dialog.text: Make your deadlines annoyingly small until action becomes a habit. Wreck procrastination with absurd constraints—ship something, then refine. Try one absurd deadline today and share what happened in the comments; reflect on how the pressure changed your pace.
dialog.instructions: Compelling, upbeat; warm call to action; friendly invitation to engage; slight urgency in closing.
